awd_titl_txt: Hankel Transform, Langlands Functoriality and Functional Equation of Automorphic L-Functions
awd_abstract_narration:
In a celebrated memoir of 1860, Riemann studied a function known as the zeta function, whose  properties imply an approximate formula for the number of prime numbers less than a given number. The optimal formula, still unproved, depends on the Riemann hypothesis on the location of zeros of the zeta function. Prior to the formulation of his celebrated hypothesis, Riemann stipulated a symmetry of the zeta function in the form of a functional equation. Thanks to the development of number theory following Riemann's memoir, we know that there is a large family of functions which includes the zeta function; these functions should encode numerical information about systems of polynomial equations, such as the number of their solutions modulo a prime number as the prime number varies. These functions should satisfy a generalized form of the Riemann hypothesis as well as a functional equation. In the early 1970s, Langlands proposed a visionary program predicting that all these functions can be viewed from a radically different perspective. This project will develop new tools that will aid in the development of Langlands' program.

Langlands' automorphic functoriality conjecture implies both meromorphic continuation and functional equation of L-functions. The functoriality conjecture remains largely unexplored beyond the endoscopic framework. In the early 2000s, Langlands (on one side) and Braverman-Kazhdan (on the other), formulated different general strategies to attack the functoriality conjecture beyond endoscopy and the functional equation of L-functions. This project aims to combine different elements of those proposals in a formulation of a new, possibly more realistic, strategy. The focus will be on the understanding of certain conjectural Schwartz spaces proposed by Braverman-Kazhdan, spaces of orbital integrals studied by Langlands and others, and the Fourier and Hankel transforms on those spaces. It is expected that geometry of arc spaces, which are infinite dimensional, will play a major role in these studies.

por.por_cntn:
Around 1970, Langlands formulated a web of conjectures that put in a new perspective some of the most important problems in number theory. In his visionary program, Langlands defined general automorphic L-functions and conjectured its meromorphic continuation and function equation as a vast generalization of Riemann's theorem on the zeta function. Prior to Langlands, Tate recasted Riemann's work on the zeta function as the Fourier theory for automorphic representation of GL(1), and Godement and Jacquet later generalized Tate's work to GL(n). Godement-Jacquet's work provided, Langlands proposed that general function equation should follow from his functoriality conjecture, and in fact is equivalent to it, and as a result, Langlands's functoriality conjecture became one of the ultimate goals of the Langlands program.

Around 2000, Braverman and Kazhdan proposed a new direct generalization of Godement-Jacquet's work to general reductive groups and representation of the dual group aiming at proving the automorphic functional equation without passing by Langlands' functoriality conjecture. The research funded by this grant is a continuation of Braverman and Kazhdan's work. It brought precision to their original conjectures and established some steps in their program. Namely, we construct an algebraic monoid asscoiated with any representation of the dual group, which specializes to the space of matrices in the Godement-Jacquet case. We constructed geometric the basic function which plays the same role as the Gaussian function in classical Fourier analysis based on the arc space of the monoid. We constructed the Hankel kernel in the toric case and made progress in its construction in the general case. 

Harmonic analysis on non-archimedean fields have closed connection with affine Springer fibers and the Hitchin fibration. Research on generalized affine Springer fibers and Hitchin fibrations, funded by this grant, has been conducted by the PI and jointly with his collaborators and PhD students.
